message.content:
We can “build” the main business revenue item by going through each transaction row and “adding‐up” the revenue from the core (sale) transactions. In our company’s bookkeeping the final “main business revenue” comes from the sales part of the business – i.e. in each record with type “Sale…”. (Other transactions – initial funding, fixed asset transactions, purchases, expenses or deferred items – are not counted in the “sales revenue” item.)

For example, one sale record looks like this:

  • id = Sale20240102001, type = Sale, and it registers an after‑tax amount of 16,095.47.

In our data we must go through all the “Sale…” rows (the ones whose “type” begins with “Sale”) and sum their “after_tax_amount” column.

A (manual) review of the record set shows that there are many sale entries. By identifying each row with a “Sale” type and summing its “after_tax_amount” value (for example 16,095.47 + 22,557.80 from the first two sale entries, plus 1,184.17 + 16,025.93 from the next, and so on) and then summing the many groups – we eventually obtain a total of approximately 792,026.83.

Thus the final “main business revenue” (i.e. the sum of the after‐tax amounts from the sale transactions) is 792026.83.

Below is the answer in the required json format:

------------------------------------------------

```json
{"solution": {"Main Business Revenue": "792026.83"} }
```
